Objects in motion. Resistance to stopping.
<[silence:2400]>
The word momentum comes from Latin momentum, meaning "movement" or "impulse"—the force that keeps things going once they start.<[silence:2400]

Imagine pushing a shopping cart.<[silence:1200]>
Empty, it stops fast when you let go.<[silence:1200]>
Filled with bricks, it rolls farther—same push, more momentum.<[silence:2400]>
Momentum depends on two things: how much stuff moves (mass) and how fast it goes (velocity).<[silence:1200]>
A bowling ball at 10 mph has more momentum than a tennis ball at 100 mph.<[silence:1200]>
Double the speed? Momentum doubles.<[silence:1200]>
Double the mass? Same effect.<[silence:2400]>

Real-world example: airbags.<[silence:1200]>
In a crash, your body’s momentum keeps it moving forward—even as the car stops.<[silence:1200]>
The airbag slows you down gradually, turning a deadly impact into a survivable push.<[silence:2400]>
Or consider space travel.<[silence:1200]>
Rockets burn fuel to gain momentum.<[silence:1200]>
In empty space, with no air resistance, they coast for years—no extra fuel needed.<[silence:2400]>

Momentum explains why ice skaters pull arms in to spin faster (less mass spread = more speed)<[silence:1200]>
...why freight trains take miles to stop<[silence:1200]>
...and why a mosquito hitting your windshield dies—but the windshield doesn’t.<[silence:2400]>

Conservation of momentum.<[silence:1200]>
In a closed system, it never disappears—just transfers.<[silence:1200]>
Billard balls.<[silence:1200]>
One strikes, energy shifts, angles change—but the total momentum stays the same.<[silence:2400]>

Friction.<[silence:1200]>
Gravity.<[silence:1200]>
Collisions.<[silence:1200]>
All just momentum in disguise.

Objects in motion. Resistance to stopping.

The word momentum comes from Latin momentum, meaning "movement" or "impulse"—the force that keeps things going once they start. <[silence:2400]

Imagine pushing a shopping cart.
Empty, it stops fast when you let go.
Filled with bricks, it rolls farther—same push, more momentum.
Momentum depends on two things: how much stuff moves (mass) and how fast it goes (velocity).
A bowling ball at 10 mph has more momentum than a tennis ball at 100 mph.
Double the speed? Momentum doubles.
Double the mass? Same effect.

Real-world example: airbags.
In a crash, your body’s momentum keeps it moving forward—even as the car stops.
The airbag slows you down gradually, turning a deadly impact into a survivable push.
Or consider space travel.
Rockets burn fuel to gain momentum.
In empty space, with no air resistance, they coast for years—no extra fuel needed.

Momentum explains why ice skaters pull arms in to spin faster (less mass spread = more speed)
. .. why freight trains take miles to stop
. .. and why a mosquito hitting your windshield dies—but the windshield doesn’t.

Conservation of momentum.
In a closed system, it never disappears—just transfers.
Billard balls.
One strikes, energy shifts, angles change—but the total momentum stays the same.

Friction.
Gravity.
Collisions.
All just momentum in disguise.
